titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Thursday.

Clear, mild and moderate weather— From Breakfast time till 3. P.M. a Succession of visitors—S. Bell, Silsbee, Nathan Smith, Southard, Thomas Ewing, H. L. White, Leonard Jarvis, I. C. Bates, Baylies, Briggs, S. C. Phillips, Lincoln, E. Everett, Grennell, Reed, W. Jackson D. J. Pearce—N. Barber, Trumbull, Miner, Ebenr Jackson, Heman Allen, H. F. Janes, Hiland Hall, W. Slade, J. Dickson, M. Fillmore, Philo C. Fuller, A. Hazeltine, G. W. Lay,—Henry C. Martindale, A. Ward, F. Whittlesey, J. Banks, G. Chambers, E. Darlington, H. Denny, W. Hiester—C. F. Mercer—J. M. Felder, T. F. Foster, James M Wayne—J. Bell, T. Corwin, Joseph H. Crane, S. F. Vinton, and others—Coll. Thomas—E Wyer—Sir Charles R Vaughan—W. P. Adams—A. Buchanan—Cavalcanti d’Albuquerque
Mr and Mrs Frye, and Thomas—Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us—
Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and means, reports the Naval Appropriation Bill for the year 1835
Bill of Appropriations on fortifications already commenced
Bill authorizing the Treasury Department to transfer the unavailable funds to the credit of the United States.
Motion made on Tuesday last by Fillmore of NY. adopted
Call on the Secretary of the Treasury for returns of hospital money, collected in the State of New-York since 1798 and how expended.

Resolution moved by Thomas of Maryland, to amend the 13th. Rule of the House, so as to admit U.S. District Attornies on the floor, was debated— Supported by Foster of Georgia Patton of Virginia moves to add, members of the State Legislatures— The Speaker said Members of the Legislatures were admitted by usage. Patton said a member of the Legislature of Virginia had recently been excluded— Beatty moved to add State judges— After debate, on motion of Hardin the Resolution was laid on the table ayes 108 Motion by Johnson of Maryland for a select Committee of inquiry to establish a National Foundery of Cannon—carried

On motion of H. Hubbard a Resolution of thanks to J. Q Adams for the Oration of the life and character of La Fayette was adopted, and another that the Chairmen of the joint Committee of Arrangements should apply to him for a copy for publication, and to receive his answer—

Gamble of Georgia, offers a Resolution to call upon the Secretary of the Treasury for his opinion whether the public revenue, may not be collected kept and disbursed without the agency of any bank or banks, and to report a plan for that purpose— Opposed by Polk and Cambreleng—lies over one day.

Orders of the day— Private Business— Bill for the relief of David Kilbourn the Canadian Spy, warmly debated, and its engrossment for the third reading, rejected by yeas and nays 94 to 97. Adjourned after 3. O’Clock.

R. M. Gamble’s Resolution, calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for his opinion, whether the Public Revenues can be kept, and disbursed without the agency of any Bank, was further discussed, and supported by a speech from A. S. Clayton, and then by Chilton Allan of Kentucky, and opposed by Polk, who says that the Secretary of the Treasury has given his opinion upon this very point, in his Report on the present mode of keeping and disbursing the public monies, and that the employment of the State Banks is no longer to be considered as an experiment; but as completely successful
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 0. At 9. P.M -2
Heard Mr Smith at the Presbyterian Church from
VI:45— Fahrenheit -16.— At 9. P.M. 16.
Thermometer this morning ten degrees lower than I ever saw it at Washington—
Morning visitors E. Wyer and James Sheridan Knowles— Evening visitors Captain Reilly and J. Connell—

H. Clay and H. Hubbard, Chairmen of the joint Committee of Arrangements of the two Houses, for carrying into effect the Resolution for the delivery of an Oration upon the life and character of La Fayette, sent for me to meet them in the Speaker’s chair
VI— Fahrenheit 8— -2. Evening visit E. Wyer.
Walk to and from the capitol—
Received and presented the Petition of Thomas Wells Dickinson for compensation, for services in the Revolutionary War—referred to the Committee on Revolutionary claims.
Gave the manuscript of my Oration to H. Hubbard, chairman of the Committee of Arrangements on the part of the House— Spoke to Mr Gales—
Polk Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means reports the general Appropriation Bill for 1835. referred to Committee of the whole on the Union.
E. Everett offers a Resolution concerning the repairs on Fort Independence in Boston Harbour.
W. C. Johnson of Maryland moves an enquiry, for a territorial Government in the District of Columbia, and for relief to the embarrassments of the District
Brown of New-York moves a call on the Secretary of the Navy for returns of pay to the Officers of the Navy, and allowances.

Hamer of Ohio offers a Resolution, instructing the Committee on the judiciary to enquire into the expediency of amending the Constitution of the United States so as to limit the services of the Judges of the Supreme and inferior Courts of the United States to a term of years—

Evans moves the question of consideration— Hubbard and Mardis call for the yeas and nays— L. Williams moves a call of the House. not carried— The house refuse to consider the motion by yeas and nays—84 to 90.
Chilton makes part of a Speech on his internal improvement Resolution

Bill to regulate the pay of the Navy Officers, at the third reading— Jones of Georgia withdraws his proposition to make, Admirals, Vice and Rear Admirals— Pope of Ohio, and Jarvis of Maine propose other Amendments— Crockett moves the previous Question which fails— Wise makes a long Speech, followed by Wayne and others—
Adjourn on the motion of Hardin at 1/2 past three.
VI:30. Thursday 8 Jany. 1835.— Fahrenheit -5.— +2
James—M’Vickar Bard— Rode to the Capitol.
The Resolution offered yesterday by E. Everett relating to the repairs of Fort Independence was adopted.
Bynum offered a new Resolution of enquiry whether commissioners or surveyors have been appointed to run the boundary line with Mexico since 1819.

E. Everett offered a Resolution, to authorize Jared Sparks to retain the Washington papers, and the Secretary of State to pay the balance of the purchase money to G. C. Washington read twice and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow

Taylor of New-York moved the reconsideration of the vote of yesterday refusing to consider the motion of inquiry for an amendment of the Constitution, limiting the Commissions of judges to a term of years—

The Speaker finally pronounced it a new motion to consider the Resolution, and not an impracticable motion to reconsider— The house now voted by yeas and nays to consider 96 to 92. Hardin moved an amendment, that they should be limited to a certain age 65 or 75— Taylor accepted the amendment—
Vance moved an Amendment, that the President should have no power to remove from Office without concurrence of the Senate
The House on motion of Parker pass to the Orders of the day.

Bill for the relief of the City of Alexandria—opposed by Hardin and Mann of New-York—supported by Chinn, chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia—and by Mercer— Rejected by the House on yeas and nays 72 to 123.

The Jackson Republicans of both Houses of Congress had a dinner at Brown’s Hotel, to celebrate conjointly the victory of New-Orleans, and the extinction of the National debt, both of which they hold as belonging to the glorification of Andrew Jackson. Adjourned at 3 O’Clock— Lane of Indiana, referring to the rejection of the Bill for the relief of the City of Alexandria, told me that he thought there was now a majority of the House of Representatives against internal improvements.
VI:15 Friday 9. Jany 1835. Fahrenheit -4.— +6
W. W. Seaton called me out and we revised the manuscript of the Oration upon the life and character of La Fayette
Wardwell from the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions reported a Bill to authorize the Secretary of War to appoint agents to examine Pensions, to prevent frauds, &c

Marshall from the Committee on Revolutionary Claims, reported a substitute for certain revolutionary claims, which with the original bill were committed to the Committee of the whole on the Union and made the special order of the day for the 30th. of January.

Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means reports a Bill, to suspend conditionally the receipt of the Bills and notes of the Bank of the United States and its branches in payment of debts, to the United States.— read twice and committed to a Committee of the whole on the State of the Union—

Polk presented also from the Secretary of the Treasury a comparative statement of domestic exchange, as charged by the U.S. Bank and the local banks—of which 10000 extra copies were ordered to be printed.
Polk gave notice that he should on Monday call up some of the Appropriation Bills—and after that some of the Bills concerning the U.S. Bank.
C. P. White from the Naval Committee reported two Bills respecting the Navy.
Sunday 11. Jany 1835— Fahrenheit 16. 34.

The first day since Friday the 2d. that the Thermometer has been any part of the day as high as the freezing point— A sample of winter such as I never before witnessed, at Washington, either for the degree or the duration of the cold. The Sky has been almost constantly clear, and the wind ranging from North to North-west. It has much abridged my diary; and sunk much of my time in idleness.

This morning at the Presbyterian Church I heard Mr Colton, from Matthew 16.26. “For what is a man profited if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own Soul? or what shall a man give in exchange for his Soul?” a magnificent specimen of the hyperbolical style— It was enchanting— The inestimable value of the Soul, was set forth in splendid imagery and language of surpassing beauty— The intellect—memory—imagination—affections, which in their combination constitute the Soul—its capacities of enjoyment and of misery, and the eternity to which it is destined or doomed furnished topics of amplification, admirably seized and managed— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the first Sunday after the Epiphany, and gave a short Sermon from Psalm 36.9 “For with thee is the fountain of life; in thy light shall we see light.” Mr Hawley commented upon the impressiveness of the Scriptural imagery— I read also the 21st. of Mr Colman’s Sermons upon the imperfection of Human knowledge—and the 22d. upon the duty of acquiescence in the Will of God—many of the remarks in this, were very affectingly applicable to my own Condition— And I closed my Sunday reading with three short chapters of William Sullivan’s Moral Class-Book—containing the proofs of the existence of God from the construction and organization of the Earth— The 23d. Psalm contains the whole of this argument.

Met the Select Committee on the Bill from the Senate for establishing the boundary between the State of Ohio, and the territory of Michigan—present H. Binney, Murphy, Dickson, and Bynum— Absent Mason of Virginia and Thomas of Maryland. After some conversation the Committee agreed to meet at ten to-morrow Morning at ten—giving notice to Lucius Lyon, the delegate from the Michigan Territory and to T. H Vinton and Willm Allen members from the State of Ohio which I gave.
Mr Heath, member from Baltimore County spoke to me, as I was going to the Committee room—

In the House, I moved by direction of the Committee on the Michigan and Ohio Boundary bill, that it be printed, which was ordered.— M’Carty of Indiana moved two Resolutions, respecting the Public Lands—one of Instructions to the Committee on Public Lands, for equalizing and reducing the Salaries of Registers and Receivers, which was adopted, and the other a call upon the President
Tuesday 13. Jany 1835— Fahrenheit 24. . . . 36.
III.— VI:45.

Rode to the Capitol. the Children with me. Met at ten O’Clock the Select Committee on the Michigan and Ohio Boundary bill from the Senate—present Binney, Murphy, Dickson, Bynum and Mason—absent Thomas of Maryland—T. H. Vinton of Ohio L. Lyon the Delegate from Michigan, and a person named Stickney, a person who lives on the disputed grounds attended— Mr Lyon addressed the Committee in support of the claim of the Michigan Territory till the Meeting of the House at 12— In the House, sundry Bills were reported, and sundry Resolutions offered— Chilton of Kentucky occupied most of the hour in discoursing upon his Resolution of Inquiry for Appropriations for internal improvements. Polk called up his Appropriation Bills— Watmough called for his Navy Officers pay bill, which was unfinished business. Polk prevailed by a bare majority of a bare quorum 65 to 56. The Pension Appropriation Bill passed without opposition or Comment— The Navy Appropriation Bill passed with very little— The army Appropriation Bill passed to a third reading after a long debate upon an amendment proposed by Polk in the Committee of the whole there rejected and renewed in the House, and there finally rejected by yeas and nays 57 to 134 It was for a claim of General Macomb of Major General’s pay from 1821 to 1828.— I had some conversation with Mr Heath which was interrupted— Walked home with Jarvis who said he believed the Committee of Foreign Affairs would Report upon French Affairs on Thursday— James M Wayne of Georgia resigned his Seat—appointed a judge of the Supreme Court, now in Session— He was Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations— Patton, a member of the Committee moved that his place should be filled— J Sergeant came and spoke to me in the house— I found Walter Hellen here on coming home Evening visits from E Whittlesey with Mr Harris and Jos Blunt.
Wednesday 14. Jany 1835. IV.30. Fahrenheit 36.

Sherburne was here and said P. Force had offered him 200 dollars for P. Jones’s manuscript— Proof sheets of Oration revised— Met the Committee of Manufactures—present, Cramer, Martindale, Ebenezer Jackson, M’Comas and Osgood— Absent Denny, Dickerson and Clowney— A memorial from Jonesborough Tennessee asking for high duties upon feathers— J Dickson’s motion to bring down to 1814 the low duties upon books printed before 1775—and Baron Roenne the Prussian Charge d’Affaires’s request that the duties on linen tape may be taken off were considered— Mr Jackson offered to write and make inquiries respecting a cotton tape manufacture in Connecticut, and upon his receiving an answer the Committee are to be called together again— In the House, I had a very short conversation with Mr Heath, who went afterwards for Baltimore

Committee of the whole on the Union, upon the Appropriation Bill for Fortifications— E. Everett moved an Amendment for 75000 dollars instead of 8000 dollars for repairs on Castle Island, in Boston Harbour—supported by B. Gorham, and opposed by Polk and Dunlap of Tennessee, and rejected— Thompson of Ohio moves an additional appropriation for Fort Marion or St Marks in Florida supported by White of Florida and rejected— Parker of N. Jersey moves to strike out the Appropriation for Throg’s Neck—answered by Ferris—motion rejected— Sevier of Arkansas moves an additional Appropriation for a substitute for Port Gibson,—which is rejected— The fortification appropriation Bill with another small bill is reported to the House, and pass to the third reading. House adjourn at half past 3. I took Governor Lincoln home— G. Grennell came to my Seat and told me that Governor John Davis would be a Candidate for Election to the Senate of the United States, by the Legislature of Massachusetts in Mr Silsbee’s place, and he supposed would be elected— Governor Lincoln, and I. C. Bates, and Edward Everett are announced also as Candidates.

Met at ten this Morning the Select Committee, on the boundary line Bill between the Territory of Michigan, and the State of Ohio— Present Binney, Murphy, Mason, Dickson and Bynum— Absent Thomas of Maryland, who for some days has not been in the house— Mr May one of the new members from the State of Illinois attended the meeting— Lyon, the delegate from Michigan concluded his argument in behalf of the Territory, and Vinton began his for Ohio. At Noon the Committee adjourned to meet at ten to-morrow in the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures—
Friday 16 Jany 1835. V.

Met at ten A.M. the Committee on the Bill of Boundary between Michigan and Ohio, at the Chamber of the Committee of Manufacture’s Present Binney, Murphy, Dickson, Mason and Bynum— Absent Thomas of Maryland— Mr Vinton continued, but did not conclude his Argument.
Saturday 17 Jany 1835— VI:15.

Met the Committee on the Michigan and Ohio boundary Bill at the Room of the Committee of Manufactures Commerce— Present Messrs Binney, Murphy, Dickson and Bynum—absent Mason and Thomas of Maryland— Mr Vinton concluded his argument in behalf of the State of Ohio, and the Committee adjourned till Monday morning at ten to hear Mr Lyon in reply.
In the House I saw General Scott, and Alderman James Monroe of New-York, who had been overset in the Stage on the road from that place— Sutherland had been with them—

Two Resolutions offered by Abijah Mann junr. of New-York, calling upon the Secretaries of War and of the Navy for returns of all the allowances and compensations made within the two last years to Officers of the Army and Navy, and the amount paid to them all—were agreed to— He said the return, could not be made in time for the action of Congress upon them at this Session, but that he should pursue the Subject at the next Session.

Leonard Jarvis moved an instruction of enquiry to the Committee of Ways and Means, for regulating the number of Clerks in the executive Departments, to avoid extra appropriations for arrears of Clerk-hire—adopted

Reynolds of Illinois, moved an instruction to the Committee on the Judiciary for extending the federal judiciary, to all the States of the Union, alike— Upon being informed the subject was already referred to that Committee on part of the President’s Message, he withdrew his motion.

There was a long debate on a reconsideration of a resolution directing the Committee on the Contingent expenses of the house to audit the accounts of the members of the Post-Office Committee who sat during the recess— No decision— Orders of the day— Bill for the relief of the legal Representatives of R. W. Meade—supported by Archer, Sutherland and E. Everett—opposed by B. Hardin— No decision— Adjourned half-past 3— Evening visits from Mr Silsbee and John Reed— Gales sent me this Evening six Copies of the Oration upon the Life and Character of La Fayette four of which I despatched by Mail—
Sunday 18. Jany 1835. VI:15. Fahrenheit 22

I went with Thomas J. Frye, and my two Grand-daughters Louisa and Fanny, to the Capitol, and heard Mr Colton, from 2. Corinthians 5.14. [“]For the love of Christ constraineth us; because we thus judge, that if one died for all, then were all dead: 15. And that he died for all, that they which live should not henceforth live unto themselves, but unto him which died for them, and rose again.” It was a discourse upon Christian philanthropy, as distinguished from philosophical, and all other kinds of philanthropy But this Mr Colton was a different person from him whom I heard at the Presbyterian Church last Sunday morning— This one is an Episcopalian, and read the morning Service of the day— The House was well filled— I paid a morning visit to Miss Harriet Martineau and Miss Jeffery her companion— She had brought me Letters of Introduction from Mr Furness of Philadelphia, and Mr Charles Brooks of Hingham; in company with whom Miss Martineau came from England— She is the author of Conversations upon political Economy, which I have not read or seen— She is a young woman, I suppose about 30—deaf, and hearing only through an Ear trumpet— Her conversation however is lively and easy, and she talks politics English, or American— I met there Mr, Mrs and Miss Webster, and Mr I. C. Bates— Mr and Mrs Frye dined and spent the Evening with us, and their Son Thomas— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the second Sunday after the Epiphany, and a stranger preached from John 3.17. [“]For God sent not his Son into the world to condemn the world: but that the world through him might be saved. 18. He that believeth on him is not condemned; but he that believeth not is condemned already because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God”— I read also two Sermons in the volume of Mr Colman— The 23d. on Man’s dependence; and the 24th. on [“]the Sins of men being chargeable to themselves”— Depressed in Spirits—
VI:15 Monday 19. Jany 1835.— Fahrenheit 18
I was belated this Morning at the Capitol
Tuesday 20. Jany 1835. V:15. Fahrenheit 28.
Reuben and Simeon Bates— S. A. Turner’s Letter 5. Sept. 1834—
De Huff John A. His Letter 15. Decr 1834
M’Intosh Peter. Papers. Artificer’s Pension
Lapham Asa Letter from J. Ford jr 2 Decr 1834

This being a day of intermission to the meeting of the Select Committee, I had a couple of leisure morning hours in which I called on Mr Richard Cutts and Mr Thomas Munroe, appointed by the judge of the Orphans Court Appraisers of the Inventory of my Son’s personal Estate— Mr Cutts was not at home, but I met him at his door, on my return from the Capitol— I saw Mr Munroe and gave him the Commission from the judge— They are to make the Appraisement next Saturday, and I gave Mr Munroe the names of T. H. Jacobs and John Walker as Creditors to be notified

I called also at the War Department; the Secretary, Cass, was not there, being detained by indisposition at home— I saw Mr Kurtz the Chief Clerk, and stated to him the claims of the persons named at the top of this page— Left their papers with him.
At the house
Wednesday 21. Jany 1835— V:30.
Met the Committee on the Michigan and Ohio Boundary; in the Chamber of the Committee of Commerce— Present, Binney, Murphy, Mason, Dickson, Bynum— Absent Thomas—

James M. Wayne was chairman of the Committee of foreign affairs— On receiving an appointment as judge of the US. Supreme Court he resigned his seat in the House, and C. C. Cambreleng was appointed on the Committee of foreign affairs in his place

My Diary runs frightfully in arrears, and I cannot retrieve it— I rode with the children to the Capitol— Immediately after the Meeting of the House, I was told that A. H. Wise, the member of the House from Virginia andCoke who was the member from the same district in the last Congress, had gone out this morning to fight a duel at Bladensburg— There was soon after a rumour that Wise was shot through the body— The reverse was the truth. Coke’s arm was broken, and had a flesh wound in the side, from the same ball.

Mr Lay paid me a morning visit with Mr Holden an inhabitant of his district, and a young man named Evans, a connection of the Vice President Van Buren’s. I attended at the House, where a skirmishing debate took place upon a motion to call upon the Secretary of War for Documents relating to the disposal of Rerservations in Indian Treaties— The object was the exposure of certain alledged enormous frauds— The debate extended beyond the hour allotted to the discussion of Resolutions but I took no part in it— My time was chiefly absorbed in directing documents to be despatched by the Mail; particularly copies of my own Oration, upon the life and character of La Fayette. Edward Howell, of New-York asked me to write my name on a copy of it, for him to send to his daughter— Edward Hannegan of Indiana brought me two with the same request; and Cave Johnson of Tennessee who is confined at his lodgings by sickness, sent me by his Colleague Dunlap six with the same solicitation— These are all devoted friends and supporters of the present Administration, and bitter political adversaries to me— I received a Letter from Joseph Williamson urging me to support the Bill for the relief of the legal Representatives of R. W. Meade, and a Letter from James Boyd, a member of the Massachusetts Legislature from Boston requesting me to prepare a Bill, for a Committee of which he is a member, for the exclusion of pauper foreigners from the State— Mrs Meade’s Bill was postponed, and a private Bill or two were passed—that for the relief of the Meade’s was postponed. The House adjourned about 3. and I walked home with Jarvis— Elliot Cresson was here in the Evening—overflowing with Colonization and emancipation projects— He gave me a pamphlet. Tyson’s Discourse before the Young men’s Colonization Society. Philadelphia.
Saturday 24. Jany 1835. V.15.

A person by the name of Sheldon came with a fulsome Note and a tribute book for a subscription to a Manual Labour School in the State of Ohio which I declined— The Appraisers of the Goods, Chattels and personal Estate of my Son, came and performed the service— Mr Frye attended them, but I was obliged to go to the Capitol and attend the Meeting of the select Committee on the Michigan and Ohio boundary line Bill— All the members of the Committee were present— After some discussion it was agreed that the Bill should be reported to the House without amendment, and with a recommendation that it do not pass All the members of the Committee agreed to this Report, excepting Mr Binney— I did accordingly report the Bill to the House— It was one of the days for private business; but the day was consumed in debating a Resolution offered by Reynolds a new member from Illinois; that the choice of the Officers of the House shall in future be made viva voce, each member rising in his place and naming the person for whom he votes— This is a party measure. The object is to secure the public printing for the next House of Representatives to the publishers of the Globe Newspaper— The Globe is openly devoted to the Vice President, Van Buren as a Candidate for the succession to the Presidency— There is a part of the Jackson party in the House, opposed to Van Buren, and who if the vote for printer should be by ballot, would vote against the publishers of the Globe if they are called to vote viva voce, it is supposed they will not dare to vote against them, for fear of the brand of opposition to the Administration— The debate was very warm, and much time was consumed in a call of the house, which was persevered in, till 21 members answered to their names— Hardin of Kentuckey moved an amendment, a proviso to except the choice of Printers—the debate continued till near 4. O’Clock— Reynolds and M’Kinley of Alabama supporting the Resolution and Fillmore of New-York— Gilmer of Georgia and Briggs of Massachusetts against it— I was occupied in despatching Documents.
Sunday 25 Jany 1835.— V:15.

At the Presbyterian Church this morning Mrpreached from 2. Timothy 4 6. “For I am now ready to be offered, and the time of my departure is at hand 7. I have fought a good fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith: 8. Henceforth, there is laid up for me a crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous judge, shall give me at that day: and not to me only, but unto all them also, that love his appearing.”—and in the afternoon at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read prayers for the third Sunday after Epiphany, and exhorted from 1. Timothy 1.15. [“]This is a faithful saying and worthy of all acceptation that Christ Jesus came into the world to save Sinners.” I read the 25th. Sermon in the Volume of Henry Colman; which is the valedictory to his Congregation of the Church in Barton Square at Salem on the 4th. of December 1831 from which he had requested and taken his discharge—and the Address to the same Society at the installation of his Successor James W. Thompson on the 7th of March 1832. this closes the volume— Mr and Mrs Frye and their Son Thomas dined with us, and spent the Evening—and I had visits from Messrs. Joseph R. Ingersoll and J. J. Milligan— Joseph Blunt and Persico. Blunt informed me of the nomination of Daniel Webster, as a Candidate for the Presidency, by a Convention of 315 members of the Massachusetts Legislature, but Blunt says he does not intend to make any more sacrifices of money or business, upon Presidential elections— Persico told me that Mr Muhlenberg had promised to offer a Resolution, for employing him further for works of Sculpture at the Capitol— And he asked me to give him a sitting, to take my bust in Marble— I promised to call at his chamber on Tuesday Morning at half past ten— I despatched a number of the La Fayette Orations.

At the House, after the call of Petitions, J. M Patton asked leave to offer a Resolution that the Committee of Foreign Relations be instructed to report three Resolutions, relating to the differences with France to which objection was made; and Patton moved the suspension of the Rules, to enable him to offer the Resolution which was rejected by yeas and nays 103 to 112.

the Resolution offered by Reynolds of Illinois, that in future all the Elections of the Officers of the House shall be made viva voce—was taken up and debated, as unfinished business. After the expiration of the hour Watmough moved that the house should pass to the orders of the day, which was rejected, and again upon the motion of I. C. Bates, who asked for the yeas and nays—but they were refused, upon which he withdrew his motion.— The Resolution was very warmly debated till past four O’Clock, by Peyton of Tennessee, who moved that the Resolution, with Hardin’s Amendment, should be referred to the Committee on the Judiciary with Instructions to report a Resolution, that the Printer of each House of Congress shall hereafter be chosen viva voce, within the first week of the first Session of each Congress— Then by Pope of Kentucky, Vanderpoel and Gillet of New-York in favour of the Resolution—and by Pearce of Rhode-Island, Clayton and Seaborn Jones of Georgia against it— Hawes of Kentucky moved the Previous Question which was rejected in count, by tellers 75 to 99— Pearce announced that he should vote for Blair, the Editor of the Globe, because he was a supporter of the Administration; and not for any supporter of John M’lean, of Judge White, or of Daniel Webster— The result of this debate, will be equivalent to a Caucus Congressional nomination of Martin van Buren, for the succession to the Presidency— I answered the Letter of James Boyd, the member of the Massachusetts Legislature— Promised to dine with W. S. Smith to-morrow.

Morning visits from Mr M’Cullock, who brought me a Letter of Introduction from Dr Condict, and John Murray, who brought one from his father at New-York— I called at Persico’s chamber; and he made some marks upon my Plaister bust— Met at 11. O’Clock, the Committee of Manufactures; present, Denny, Cramer, Dickerson, Clowney, Martindale, and Osgood—absent M’Comas and Jackson of Connecticut, who afterwards informed me in the house that he had forgotten the appointment for this morning’s meeting— The Committee determined unanimously to ask to be discharged from the further consideration of the Memorial from Jonesborough Tennessee, praying for heavy duties on feathers, and also of Dickson’s motion for reducing the duties on certain books, and that they would not recommend the removal of the duties on linen tape— In the house Love, from the Committee on Indian Affairs, to whom, M’Carty’s Resolution upon Indian Reservations was referred, reported an amended Resolution, which gave rise to a long and knotty debate, which intercepted the reports from all other Committees, in which Clay and M’Kinley of Alabama, Plummer of Mississippi and Ewing and Lane of Indiana, took part, and some heat occurred between the two last— After a sharp speech from Lane, Polk called for the orders of the day. After several communications from the departments, and the progress of certain Bills and Resolutions, the General Appropriation Bill was taken up, and the amendment offered by Mr Vance was debated till near four O’Clock, by Vance, Cambreleng, Sutherland, Fillmore, Pope, Phillips, Ward, Williams, Gillet and Harper. M’Kinley moved the previous Question, but was not seconded by the house— The House adjourned about four— I walked home, and then to Mr W. S. Smith’s where I dined— Judge Nathanl Pope Mr Thomas Munroe, John Connell and Mr and Mrs Frye were there— In the evening I walked home— Wrote to my Son, and despatched about one hundred copies of the Oration upon the Life and character of La Fayette.
Sarah Drew. Letter 14 Jany 1835. Copy of mustering order

Call at the War Department, and the Secretary being engaged I left with the Chief Clerk the names of these two persons, and the request for copies of their papers desired by the Letters— At the House— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures, the request to be discharged from the further Consideration of the Memorial of the Inhabitants of Jonesborough Tennessee, asking that heavy duties be laid upon feathers, and of the Resolution offered by Mr Dickson, proposing an alteration of the duties upon Books, which report was laid on the table— I then had leave to present the Petition from Inhabitants of Quincy, Milton and Braintree for an alteration of the Patent Law— I moved its reference to the Committee of the Judiciary; but on the suggestion of the Chairman of that Committee Foster, that they had reported a Bill conformable to the prayer of the Petition, which was now before the House, the Petition was laid on the table— I asked the permission of the House to offer a Resolution, calling upon the President, for a further correspondence with the French Government, and despatches, from our Minister in France, relating to the failure of France to pay the money stipulated by the Treaty of 4 July 183. . .

Morning visit from Mr Hassler, who is occupied upon the survey of the Coast, and who as usual had a detail of grievances about his accounts, and the refusal of the fourth Auditor, and the Secretary of the Navy to allow for his necessary expenses, among which are a barouche and horses which he uses in Summer upon the survey and keeps in Winter here at Washington— Immediately after the Meeting of the House, and reading of the Journal,Pickens, the member from South Carolina, who comes in the place of G. M’Duffie, announced the decease of his Colleague Warren R. Davis, who died at Dowson’s, about seven O’Clock this Morning.— He has been about a fortnight in the City, but had not taken his seat in the House— Mr Pickens pronounced a short panegyric upon the deceased, who was a high spirited man, of some wit a lively imagination, and honest though satirical good humour—a fair specimen of the South-Carolina character— Mr Pickens moved the usual orders that the house would attend the funeral to-morrow at Noon, and that the members would wear crape for thirty days—and the order that the Senate should be notified of the decease of Mr Davis— The Speaker appointed the Committee of Arrangements for the funeral, and the House immediately adjourned— I came home and received a visit from Mr Vanderpoel, member from the House of Representatives from Kinderhoek, and one in the Evening from Mr Thatcher who brought me a Letter of introduction from William Lee at Boston— The remainder of the day was occupied in answering a Letter from B. F. Hallett, and in despatching copies of the Oration upon the Life and Character of La Fayette.
V.15 Friday 30. Jany 1835.

Rode to the Capitol, and attended the funeral of Warren Ransom Davis, a member of the House of Representatives from South-Carolina— The Service was performed by Mr Hatch, the Chaplain of the Senate, according to the forms of the Episcopal Church— Mr Preston the Senator from the State said to me that I had lost in Davis a devoted friend—and I believe it was true. Nearly the last words he ever spoke in the House were, that he hoped God would forgive him for the past he had taken in 1828 against me; for he never should forgive himself— I rode to the grave-yard with Charles G. Ferris from New-York— As we were descending the broad flight of steps from the Rotunda, on the Eastern front of the Capitol, I heard the snap of a Pistol—sounding like a squib— It was aimed at the president of the United States, by an insane man named Lawrence, and it was said he snap’d a second pistol, but I heard only one report— They both missed fire. The incident occasioned some commotion; but the funeral procession was not delayed— The number of the members who followed it however was not so great as usual— From the grave-yard I returned with Mr Ferris to the Capitol, where there came only the Speaker, and one or two other members— He took the Chair, and at my motion adjourned the House— I walked home, stopping on the way to Gadsby’s tavern, to return the visit of Mr Reverdy Johnson of Baltimore. Left cards also for N Williams, J. P. Kennedy, Mr M’Culloch, and Alderman James Monroe of New-York— I apologised to Mr Johnson for not having answered a Letter which I received from him shortly before I came from Quincy— Mrs Johnson was with her husband—very pretty— This Evening I was visited by Mr Amos Davis, a member of the House from Kentucky with a friend of his by the name of Minafy— The remainder of the Evening was absorbed in directing copies of my Oration upon La Fayette, to members of the Legislature of Massachusetts. Heavy Thunder and Lightening.

Dr Julius, brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Duponceau of Philadelphia— Dr Julius is a commissioner, sent by the Prussian Government to this Country to visit and examine the Prisons and Penitentiaries, for the purpose of introducing improvements into those of Prussia— He is well acquainted with the work of Messrs. de Beaumont and Tocqueville, and spoke of it in terms of qualified approbation. He said there would shortly be published a Report of a Mr Crawford who had been sent here by the British Government and was in the United States last year, which would be more full and satisfactory than that of the French Commissioners, and that he had read Mr Crawford’s Manuscript— Mr John Connell called upon me, and said it had occurred to him that it would be proper for the House of Representatives to pass some Resolution expressive of their abhorrence of the attempt yesterday to assassinate the President, and that I was the proper person to offer such a Resolution— That he had mentioned his thoughts to Mr Webster; who concurred entirely in the opinions—particularly as there was an Article in the Globe imputing this act of the Assassin to the Speeches of Senators against the President— I told Mr Connell, that I did not wish to meddle with this affair politically at-all— The man was in prison—to be dealt with according to Law— What was his motive I knew not—nor who, if any one, was his instigator— I saw no necessity for me to be officious on the occasion— At the House C. F. Mercer came to my seat and asked if I did not think the House should appoint a Committee to investigate the transaction, which occurred while the House was formally in Session— I said no—at least I saw no propriety for my moving in the matter— In the House, Gilmer Chairman of the select Committee on so much of the Message as relates to an Amendment of the Constitution, in relation to Presidential Elections, moved the discharge of the Committee, who cannot agree upon any thing, and offered a long amendment of his own which was ordered to be printed— My call upon the President for copies of correspondence concerning the dispute with France, was adopted without opposition— The day was employed upon private Bills, in Committee of the whole, and in the House.
